abundance guesstimation:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4qed","text":"My observation from running SDS-PAGE gels with 5ul protein markers beside BSA standards is that the apparent intensities of most bands in the markers correspond to the intensity you get from BSA standards loaded at 250-500ng protein lane, after staining with Instant Blue. So it’s possible to make rough guesses at the FP concentration per OD just by looking at the markers. However, this isn’t generally necessary, and more information can be gotten from comparing the relative intensity of the band corresponding to your FP to the other bands in a particular lane. If the FP is clearly visible in the induced vs uninduced lanes, there’s some reasonable expression, and if it is mainly in the soluble fraction that is good news. Further, if it is one of the strongest bands in the soluble fraction that’s all you need to know - your FP is expressing at very high levels (it is one of the most abundant proteins per cell) without causing toxicity, and most of it is soluble so it should be easy to purify.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":51,"length":15}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"58C4E5B03DD511EC936C75FE0CC2172A","height":264.4864864864869,"id":190422,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":66,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"3o5pg","text":"Gel1: mScarlet expresses well and is found in the soluble fraction","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"gel1_mscarlet.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f382bn6df.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f38ybn6df.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f38zbn6df.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f38xbn6df.webp","width":212.73913043478288}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"url":"https://international.neb.com/products/p7712-color-prestained-protein-standard-broad-range-11-245-kda#Product%20Information"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"49utn","text":"There are a number of ways to purify His-tagged proteins. I opted for the HisPur Cobalt resin for a few reasons. Resins are available in agarose bead and magnetic bead format - magnetic beads are attractive for high throughput and automated protocols, but their binding capacities are 100-1000fold lower per volume than agarose resins. While I don’t need grams of protein, I did require ug-mg yields, so it had to be agarose. The most popular resin is the Nickel resin (NiNTA) but I opted for Cobalt because, while its capacity is lower this is not a problem at the scales I require, but its specificity is higher ensuring purer protein.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bnhua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"874ds","text":"Back of the envelope calculation to illustrate:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5oleb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3r1i5","text":"HisPur Cobalt resin. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":19}],"data":{}},{"key":"92ubk","text":"    Capacity of the resin: 10mg/ml (lower than NiNTA but higher specificity).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35h4a","text":"spin columns ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbslf","text":"    I use Pierce Spin Columns - Snap Cap. The standard/smallest one has a max volume of 300ul 50% resin, which means a total yield of 3mg protein can be obtained from Cobalt resins, or 20mg protein max from NiNTA. This is typically sufficient: assuming all protein ends up in one quant assay, we’re talking a starting conc for the highest conc in the plate would be (E1 neat: 3mg/100ul = 3000ug/100ul = 30ug/ul; E1/10 =) 3ug/ul. If I get a conc of 500ng/ul here I’m happy (6x less). Minimum is probably 100ng/ul (30x less).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":10,"length":30}],"data":{}},{"key":"781a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1jja","text":"Nickel and Cobalt resins tolerate most common reagents except EDTA (so there’s no EDTA in the lysis buffer). DTT is disputed - manual for HisPur says to avoid it completely. DTT use (1mM) was tested and found to make not much difference to purification yields. Meaning DTT 1mM shouldn’t negatively affect the columns. Subsequently however I didn’t use it because it interferes w microBCA assays, and FPs seem happy enough without (but many of them only have a single Cys anyway).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56l9j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38jel","text":"[ {"blocks":[{"key":"aotdv","text":"I do a buffer exchange every time (to T5N15-+pi) because it is essential for microBCA and A280 assay accuracy. If microBCA assays are used, and BSA standards are being used, it is best to treat the BSA in parallel with the FPs to make sure the buffers are identical. However, if only ECmax assays are going to be done, technically this step is optional. T5N15 + pi should be made fresh. There is no data on pi stability so in practise I never use >1day old buffer. Filter sterilise to get rid of cloudy precipitate (doesn’t disappear even when dissolved at 37oC. According to the manual, this is normal, but it may interfere with assays.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":638}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3j9bg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f57kp","text":"Minimum concentrations for FP elutions in the next steps are > 100 ng/ul, as the highest conc to be measured in will be Elution/10, and 10 ng/ul is still within range of the protein assays. It usually makes sense to merge all elutions before starting.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8okc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3nog5","text":"Notes before starting:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eastn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"984bh","text":"As E1>>E2>>E3, combining all three and concentrating back to the original volume of E1, 300ul, is unlikely to make a big difference in the conc of E1 pre-concentration to conc of E123 post-concentration. However, it should increase. But if this is further concentrated to 100ul then at least a 3X increase in concentration should result.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ul53","text":"Amicons claim 100 mM imidazole is the maximum compatibility of the columns. The elutions contain 150 mM. So technically the first step should be to DILUTE the elution 2-fold, but in practice it works fine as is.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b6sju","text":"Amicons are not compatible with >0.1% Triton X100 and Triton can interfere w A280 absorbance in protein assays. If sonication was used, no problem. If Triton was used, typically this means there’s 0.1% in the lysis buffer. If the bound resin was washed with 10 column volumes of Triton-free buffer, perhaps Triton shouldn’t be an issue, but this hasn’t been tested.
","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a10p6","text":"Amicon concentration can be taken as an opportunity for buffer exchange, eg. dilute out imidazole and protease inhibitors and buffer exchange from T50N300 to T5N15. But obviously to compare different proteins they should be treated the same. Note: for the experiments in the paper, I (i) merged and concentrated E1+E2+E3 (900ul) to 50ul, (ii) buffer exchanged (3x450ul) into T5N15 and made up to 100ul, (iii) split the FPs into 2x50ul and buffer exchanged (3x450ul) either into T5N15 again, or T5N15+pi. Step (ii) was required to remove imidazole, and step (iii) to add pi back to one half of the sample, because I wanted to compare T5N15 and T5N15+pi in the following assays. In practise, it makes sense to do only one buffer exchange, straight into your buffer of choice.

{"blocks":[{"key":"4cfv1","text":"The idea behind this protocol is to make most efficient use of protein. Therefore, ideally, one 100ul aliquot of the merged/concentrated Elution (E123), is all that is needed for all the fluorescence and concentration assays, and these can be done consecutively on a single dilution series. Currently an ‘exhaustive’ workflow includes 1 fluorescence assay and 3 protein assays. As this is the ‘exhaustive’ protocol, I will list a workflow to do all three.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e8jc2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tuug","text":"Summary:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1hv50","text":"You will need 100ul elution of each FP to be calibrated; plus 100ul of 2mg/ml BSA; plus the microBCA kit.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16lgq","text":"Access to all plate readers to be calibrated for a clear few hours is ideal, but the time required depends entirely on ambition: the number of instruments, channels and FPs.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5fitm","text":"Prep dilutions as 225ul/well in a uvclear plate -\u003e absorbance scans.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1d59a","text":"Transfer 200ul to clear plates (the same type of plate as you use for bacterial assays) -\u003e fluorescence quants.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4r8p","text":"Transfer 150ul to new clear plate -\u003e microBCA.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3v912","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2srs5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"biufd","text":"There are three protein concentration assays (‘protein assays’) in this workflow.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b215q","text":"microBCA assay","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c272j","text":"A280 assay","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64krc","text":"ECmax assay","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"esq95","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fmprs","text":"As A280 and ECmax are simply absorbance assays, they need to be done before a microBCA, if multiple concentration measurements are going to be done. In addition, the A280 assay requires a different sort of plastic - uvclear plates. These absorb far less in the UV range and allow us to pick up protein signals at A280 that wouldn’t be possible with standard polystyrene. Therefore, this requires an extra step that I decided to do before the fluorescence assay. While in principle it shouldn’t matter, transferring samples between plates is not loss-free, and A280 assays are not typically very sensitive. Therefore, using as much as possible for the A280 is ideal - I went for 225ul, as 2x225ul can reliably be pipetted from a 500ul dilution series.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehu6g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3umej","text":"Therefore plates to scan in order are:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ui08","text":"225ul uvclear - a280/ecmax","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"camu8","text":"200ul clear - fluor","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1vua3","text":"150ul clear - microbca","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gfv5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pdqt","text":"–","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2cp97","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"csauv","text":"[ Day 2 contd ]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6uc2p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51o6u","text":"Prepare dilutions of BSA in parallel with FPs to allow for parallel treatment of BSA/FPs and microBCA standardisation later. Run scans in plate reader for FP quantification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"60nbf","text":"1. Make Protein Dilutions in Eppies","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5u2d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j6i","text":"In order to validate the protein quantitation assays, I dilute each FP using serial dilutions and measure the concentration and fluorescence of each. In order to maximise both the dilution series and the number of FPs quantifiable per plate, I typically arrange FPs in 96-well plates in pairs of rows (AB, CD, EF, GH) - each FP is therefore measured as a duplicate. This leaves the columns for the dilution series itself, with 11 used for protein dilutions, and one for the buffer. (NB: In theory, arranging FPs in columns, with 7 dilutions plus one buffer for each FP, would allow for 6 proteins to be measured at the same time.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ei8nt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77bq4","text":"If the microBCA assay is to be used, you need one BSA dilution per plate, or two if the two FPs to be measured are in different buffers (each FP/buffer combination needs a corresponding BSA/buffer dilution).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3oj27","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j77g","text":"I {"blocks":[{"key":"e0r9u","text":"3. Measure absorbance in UVClear plate - A280 and ECmax assays","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cp7ir","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ar1s5","text":"Prewarm plate reader to temp used for cell growth curve assays to make sure the calibrations are valid for those temperatures - eg. 30oC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ei0oc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ef323","text":"Plate reader runs with UVClear plate:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5r45s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"14ns9","text":"    instrument plate lid scan time taken     1 instrument1 uvclear none A200-1000 2 min   ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":90}],"data":{}},{"key":"3lv7g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eei83","text":"Only one scan is needed here. That is an absorbance scan between 200nm and 1000nm. On the Spark this is the maximum range you can do, and you don’t need more anyway. But the UV end is important for A280 measurements, the middle for ECmax, and the top for path length quantification. It also encompasses the A562nm baseline quantification for the microBCA assay.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b9hgo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fp5uk","text":"Other runs can also be done optionally. Scans with a seal can be done if evaporation is a worry (in practice with 225ul it shouldn’t be), but be aware that seals can distort absorbance readings particularly at A280 so it’s not recommended. I sometimes run an extra, shorter, scan of 400nm-800nm as this lets me visualise the FP peaks by eye and verify easily that there is a decent amount of FP in the purification(s). (BFP in particular is not visible by eye, so the elution colour doesn’t tell you how much of it you have purified!)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3aqk4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"1_0":"","1_1":"","1_2":"","1_3":"","1_4":"","1_5":""},"colTitles":["","instrument","plate","lid","scan","time taken"],"colWidths":[100,100,100,100,100,100],"data":[["1","instrument1","uvclear","none","A200-1000","2 min"]],"guid":"17CB58503DDA11EC936C75FE0CC2172A","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":"","mergeCells":{},"printData":[["1","instrument1","uvclear","none","A200-1000","2 min"]],"rowHeights":[23]}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"93b7e","text":"The purpose of this step is to quantify the fluorescence of each FP dilution in the same plate that the E. coli growth curves will be carried out in.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":77,"length":71}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vg7q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mqc","text":"[    instrument plate lid scan time taken     1 instrument in which the microBCA assay will be done clear none or seal A200-1000 2 min   2 instrument1 clear seal FP-dependent fluorescence channel1 10min ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":408}],"data":{}},{"key":"52gt0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1qrb","text":"I usually run another absorbance scan here with or without a seal (without is ‘nicer’ but evaporation should be taken into account for longer incubation times above 25oC). Alternatively, if the ECmax assay is the only protein assay to be used, the uvclear plate step can be skipped in favour of running an absorbance scan here.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79gom","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5neha","text":"Fluorescence data should be gathered on a range of gains (I use 40-120), for one (or more) channels, as required. For eg. while mScarlet is best measured at emission channel 595/35, it can be useful to measure it in 620/20 as well, in cases where the 595/35 channel would pick up too much crosstalk from another FP (such as YFP).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"asiuc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75q64","text":"How I name channels (filter sets):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brftv","text":"Channels are named as a combination of the excitation, then emission filter, which are given names to indicate the region of the visible spectrum they cover, followed by numbers. eg. the standard GFP filter set is ‘green1green2’, which excites at wavelength 485nm (bandwidth 20nm) and measures emission at wavelength 535nm (bandwidth 25nm).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4calp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"1_0":"","1_1":"","1_2":"","1_3":"","1_4":"","1_5":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","2_2":"","2_3":"","2_4":"","2_5":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","3_2":"","3_3":"","3_4":"","3_5":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","4_2":"","4_3":"","4_4":"","4_5":"","5_0":"","5_1":"","5_2":"","5_3":"","5_4":"","5_5":""},"colTitles":["","instrument","plate","lid","scan","time {"blocks":[{"key":"13qej","text":"[ Day 3 contd ]","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6arg5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be3pv","text":"The third FP concentration assay is the microBCA. Note that as the microBCA assay requires the addition of a reagent to your FP that cannot be easily separated again, this step needs to be the last in the workflow - after quantification of protein via A280/ECmax and after fluorescence assays.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"38h5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71cmk","text":"Why microBCA is ideal:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"218jd","text":"It has low protein to protein variation (11%, much lower than Coomassie-based assays).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bo96p","text":"Its sensitivity of microplate version is linear at 2-40 ng/ul. (The test tube version of the microBCA protocol is apparently more sensitive but for that you’d need (a) 1ml of protein, (b) to incubate the plate at 60oC which polystyrene plates can’t handle.)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dojqi","text":"It is optimised for microplates / high-throughput measurements.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27hkm","text":"As a colourimetric reaction, it can be verified (sanity check) by eye.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cpm6u","text":"It includes its own BSA standards in ampule format.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"59ebr","text":"It is tolerant to detergents (\u003c5% Triton), if that’s ever a requirement.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1cla","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9fu5","text":"Watch out, though - microBCA is sensitive to buffer:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3efm","text":"High conc TBS (T50N300) leads to an inhibition of reaction.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b62h7","text":"1X PBS leads to a background reaction (observed).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ksgk","text":"Protease inhibitors also have some background (because two of the inhibitors are actually peptides!).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"abm76","text":"DTT and reagents that chelate copper are not tolerated.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5al41","text":"Specific single amino acids will also produce color in the BCA assay (cysteine, tyrosine, and tryptophan).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ddrqh","text":"3. MicroBCA assay","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ah5b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f140q","text":"3A. Prepare reagents","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be144","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4lr0g","text":"The MicroBCA kit makes this step super simple. Just mix the three reagents, these are stable at RT for at least a few hours and don’t need protecting from light. I make them up ahead of time while the fluorescence scans are running.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rt4s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ldf5","text":"Working reagent (WR) to make up: #columns(incl buffer) * #rows * 150ul = WR needed.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ed9l","text":"I typically only do the assay for the first 8 dilutions + buffer, as this is beyond the sensitivity of the assay in all cases.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ojvu","text":"So a full plate would need: 9 * 8 * 150ul = 10.8ml. Round up to 12ml.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fi33t","text":"WR components need to be mixed in the ratio 25A:24B:1C.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a0b9j","text":"Calculation: (Total volume)/50 = 1 part. eg. 12ml/50 = 240ul. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6mt60","text":"    A = 25*part = 6ml","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6okff","text":"    B = 24*part = 5.76ml","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e222u","text":"    C = 1*part = 240ul","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"amhko","text":"Vortex.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"66u62","text":"Distribute into in new clear plate with multipipette (Dispensing mode; 5ml; 150ul * 18; Asp 4, Disp 5).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"60j24","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f383k","text":"3B. Prepare samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1h63n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbclm","text":"Add 150ul from most recent plate (200ul clear plate or 180 black plate) into corresponding wells - use multichannel and mix carefully by pipetting up/down.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2hbqb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6cig6","text":"3C. Reaction and Measurement (in plate reader)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dn8n0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2dcbb","text":"Both incubation and measurement is done in a plate reader. This ensures an even distribution of heat compared to ventilated incubators and ensures that the cooling to 25oC step is done properly - I can’t control the room temperature or measure the temperature of the plate contents if I cool a plate by putting it on the bench.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dnruf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3j231","text":"assay, 37oC 2h ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eh1g5","text":"how to program:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8fmkt","text":"    temp 37oC, ‘await temp before continuing’, unselect ‘stop temp control after this step’","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32ejc","text":"    “wait” step, 2h","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7cdd1","text":"cool to RT, 25oC 10’ ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fo9ja","text":"    how to program:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64uis","text":"    temp 25oC, ‘await temp before continuing’, unselect ‘stop temp control after this step’","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gdqd","text":"    “wait” step, 10’","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"hoia","text":"measurement at A562nm ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5elh8","text":"    how to program:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vd12","text":"    Absorbance measurement, 562 nm, rest of settings on defaults.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkqeh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"oerl","text":"This takes about 2h30 as the cooling takes time. NB. If the cooling takes \u003e30min, eg. in the summer in a poorly air-conditioned lab, it is best to switch off the ‘await temp before continuing’ step.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"chcvi","text":"Proteins should be stored in the fridge protected from the light, which testing indicated kept proteins stable and active for up to 4 weeks. Long term storage and re-testing post freeze-thaw has not been tested.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6p87j","text":"The aim of this protocol is that for a given FP, we can relate the number of FP molecules to the 'relative' fluorescence units observed in a given instrument, with a given filter set, and gain. The previous steps described how to purify FPs to produce calibrants and how to run the assays. The output data from such assays must now be analysed to obtain calibrations. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8dpeh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6sgir","text":"To assist with this process, we have developed an R package called FPCountR. The full details are on the GitHub page. In brief, functions in this package are provided for each analytical step. parser() functions parse plate reader data into idealised formats. get_concentration() functions calculate protein concentration from absorbance data. The generate_cfs() function obtains conversion factors using concentration and fluorescence data. Finally, process_plate() and calc_percell() functions extract data from microbial growth curves in units of molecules, and molecules/cell.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
